lines.text: How do you tell a child that she was born to be hurt?
[Sarah Jane enters carrying a serving tray on her head]

[affected Southern Negro accent]
Fetched y'all up a mess 'a crawdads, Miss Lora... fo' you an' yo' friends!
Well, that's quite a trick, Sarah Jane... where did you learn it?

[affected Southern Negro accent]
Oh, 'tain't no trick ta' totin', Miss Lora! I learned it from my mammy, an' she learned it from ol' massa, 'fo' she belonged to you...
Now, just a moment, young lady! It's only because of my ambition that you've had the best of everything. And that's a solid achievement that any mother can be proud of!

[tearfully]
And how about a mother's love?
LOVE? But you've always had that!
Yes, by telephone, by postcard, by magazine interviews... you've given me everything... but yourself!
You're aiming high.
Why not? It doesn't cost anymore. Don't you believe in chasing rainbows?
Well, I'm going up and up and up - and nobody's going to pull me down!

[to Sarah Jane]
You weren't being colored, you were just being childish.
Miss Lora, we just come from a place where... where my color deviled my baby. Now, anything here has gotta be better.
I'm someone else. I'm white... white... WHITE!
I'd be happy knowin' you're meetin' nice young folk...
Busboys! Cooks! Chauffeurs!
[Hmph]
Like Hawkins. No thank you; I've seen your "nice young folk".
I don't wanna fight with you, honey. Not tonight. I don't feel too good. While I get started on the anchovies, will you take this tray in to Miss Lora and her friends?

[sarcastic]
Why, certainly. Anything at all for Miss Lora and her friends.
Your bones...
What about my bones?
They're perfect. My camera could easily have a love affair with you.
Miss Lora, you don't know what it means to be... different...

[to mother Annie]
I wouldn't be caught dead in a colored teachers' college!
So, honeychile, you had a mammy!
Yes. All my life.
